thread.title: Caitlyn Jenner warns President Trump: 'We'll see you in court'
thread.title_full: Caitlyn Jenner warns President Trump: 'We'll see you in court' | Washington Examiner

author: Caitlin Yilek
title: Caitlyn Jenner warns President Trump: 'We'll see you in court'
text:
Transgender reality television star Caitlyn Jenner is calling the Trump administration's decision to repeal guidelines on public school bathrooms for transgender students "a disaster."
The former Olympian released a video Thursday on Twitter, reminding President Trump that he made "a promise to protect the LGBTQ community."
Well @realDonaldTrump , from one Republican to another, this is a disaster. You made a promise to protect the LGBTQ community. Call me. pic.twitter.com/XwYe0LNUOq — Caitlyn Jenner (@Caitlyn_Jenner) February 24, 2017 
"I have a message for the trans kids of America," Jenner says in the video. "You're winning. I know it doesn't feel like it today or every day, but you're winning."
  Jenner then sharpened her tone and took  
"Now I have a message for the bullies: You're sick," she said. "And because you're weak you pick on kids, you pick on women or anyone else you think is vulnerable. Apparently even becoming the attorney general isn't enough to cure some people of their insecurities."
Jenner then mentioned transgender teen Gavin Grimm, whose family is suing his school after the school board prohibited him from using the boys bathroom. The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear oral arguments in the case in March.
"Mr. President, we'll see you in court," Jenner warned.
In April, Trump said Jenner would be free to use any bathroom she wanted in Trump Tower.
  Pence likens Trump to Reagan in 'conviction, vision and courage' 
OXON HILL, Md. — Vice   told thousands of conservative activists Thursday evening that President Trump has succeeded in giving a voice to most Americans like no other Republican leader "since Reagan."
"From the outset, our president reminded me of somebody else," Pence, alluding to the 40th president, said in remarks at the annual   Conference.
"I believe he has given voice to the aspirations and frustrations of the American people like no one since Reagan," he added.
Pence, who was awarded the Charlton Heston Courage Under Fire Award, said he knew from the moment he agreed to serve as Trump's second-in-command that "our president would reignite [the conservative]
By Gabby Morrongiello • 02/23/17 8:17
